item.title: Here are the 2025 Bafta nominees and our predictions who will win
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/03/05/2025-bafta-nominees-predictions/

The 2025 Video Game Baftas will take placed on April 8th and will be streamed live at 7pm on BAFTA’s YouTube and Twitch channels, but who will be winning a famous trophy? Here are all the nominees… along with our predictions.

Best Game

• Astro Bot
• Balatro
• Black Myth: Wukong
• Helldivers 2
• The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom
• Thank Goodness You’re Here!

Prediction: A strong category, but it has to be Astro Bot, the plucky PlayStation mascot who has charmed the whole planet (and won our own Game of the Year award in December)

Animation

• Astro Bot
• Call of Duty: Black Ops 6
• Lego Horizon Adventures
• Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Thank Goodness You’re Here!
• Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2

Prediction: Harder to call this one, as Hellblade 2 once again comes with excellent performance capture and animation… but it’s probably going to be Astro Bot again, if only for the huge amount of incidental animations that you can trigger.

Artistic Achievement

• Astro Bot
• Black Myth: Wukong
• Harold Halibut
• Neva
• Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Still Wakes the Deep

Prediction: Harold Halibut’s stop motion animation seems to be the perfect winner for this category. It took eleven years to complete so that must deserve an award and this is probably more fitting than lifetime achievement!

Audio Achievement

• Animal Well
• Astro Bot
• Helldivers 2
• Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Star Wars Outlaws
• Still Wakes the Deep

Prediction: Hellblade 2’s binaural recording and mixing is going to win this, no question.

British Game

• A Highland Song
• Lego Horizon Adventures
• Paper Trail
• Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Still Wakes the Deep
• Thank Goodness You’re Here!

Prediction: There are some very British games in this category, but the slapstick Yorkshire humour of Thank Goodness You’re Here! is probably going to win.

Debut Game

• Animal Well
• Balatro
• Pacific Drive
• Tales of Kenzera: Zau
• Thank Goodness You’re Here!
• The Plucky Squire

Prediction: Another strong category, but you can’t ignore the behemoth that is Balatro.

Evolving Game

• Diablo 4
• Final Fantasy 14
• No Man’s Sky
• Sea of Thieves
• Vampire Survivors
• World of Warcraft

Prediction: This one could go anywhere, but Sea of Thieves, Final Fantasy 14 and No Man’s Sky have won this category before, so maybe it’s time for Diablo 4.

Family

• Astro Bot
• Cat Quest 3
• Lego Horizon Adventures
• Little Kitty, Big City
• The Plucky Squire
• Super Mario Party Jamboree

Prediction: Astro Bot. 100%.

Game Beyond Entertainment

• Botany Manor
• Kind Words 2
• Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Tales of Kenzera: Zau
• Tetris Forever
• Vampire Therapist

Prediction: Another hard one to guess, but Bafta do go for some odd choices now and then, so and if Hellblade 2 is getting wins elsewhere it might be Vampire Therapist.

Game Design

• Animal Well
• Astro Bot
• Balatro
• Helldivers 2
• The Legend of Zelda: Echoes of Wisdom
• Tactical Breach Wizards

Prediction: While none of these games bring anything particularly new to the table they all play exceptionally well. Let’s go with Astro Bot again.

Multiplayer

• Call of Duty: Black Ops 6
• Helldivers 2
• Lego Horizon Adventures
• Super Mario Party Jamboree
• Tekken 8
• Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2

Prediction: Well it won’t be Lego Horizon Adventures – it’s fun, but no – and I have a feeling this will either go to Warhammer or Helldivers. I am going with Helldivers 2.

Music

• Astro Bot
• Black Myth: Wukong
• Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth
• Helldivers 2
• Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Star Wars Outlaws

Prediction: A completely open field here, and it really depends on what sort of music you like really. It would be nice to see Black Myth: Wukong win something,

Narrative

• Black Myth: Wukong
• Dragon Age: The Veilguard
• Final Fantasy 7 Rebirth
• Metaphor: ReFantazio
• Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Still Wakes the Deep

Prediction: I am going for Still Wakes The Deep in this category. There’s some great games like Metaphor: ReFantazio, but Still Wakes The Deep is a British game which gives it the edge.

New Intellectual Property

• Animal Well
• Balatro
• Black Myth: Wukong
• Metaphor: ReFantazio
• Still Wakes the Deep
• Thank Goodness You’re Here!

Prediction: This is a bit of a weird category as Still Wakes the Deep and Thank Goodness You’re Here! really don’t need to become franchises in the way that IP implies, and Balatro might be novel, but it’s card game and – no offence to creators – they didn’t invent the standard card deck or the Poker hands it uses. We think this will go to Metaphor: ReFantazio.

Performer in a Leading Role

• Alec Newman, Still Wakes the Deep
• Humberly González, Star Wars Outlaws
• Isabella Inchbald, Indika
• Luke Roberts, Silent Hill 2
• Melina Juergens, Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Y’lan Noel, Call of Duty: Black Ops 6

Prediction: This is almost certainly a second BAFTA for Melina Juergens.

Performer in a Supporting Role

• Abbi Greenland and Helen Goalen, Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Aldís Amah Hamilton, Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Jon Blyth, Thank Goodness You’re Here!
• Karen Dunbar, Still Wakes the Deep
• Matt Berry, Thank Goodness You’re Here!
• Michael Abubakar, Still Wakes the Deep

Prediction: This could be anyone, but let us hope it’s Matt Berry just for the acceptance speech.

Technical Achievement

• Astro Bot
• Black Myth: Wukong
• Call of Duty: Black Ops 6
• Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2
• Tiny Glade
• Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine 2

Prediction: Given that Ninja Theory went to a lot of trouble to tell everyone they had travelled to Iceland to scan every rock and blade of grass, it’s going to be Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2. The game really does look incredible.

Do you agree with our predictions? Let us know in the comments.

Source:  BAFTA

item.title: Glover (QUByte Classics) Review
item.content:encoded:
https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/03/05/glover-qubyte-classics-review/

The closest I came to playing Glover before 2025 was back when I worked at CEX. There was a copy of the game just sat on the shelf for years and years while i worked there, nobody ever being tempted to buy it before I left. It might even be there to this day! It’s a game that came in that first wave of 3D platformers, with the twist that you’re a magical glove that handles balls. Bouncy, bowling, and metal balls, that is.

The story of Glover sees a spell go wrong with a wizard falling out of a tower, getting himself frozen in place. Not his gloves, though. Glover sets off on a mission to retrieve the crystals to restore things back to normal, while his opposite number has nefarious plans to stop Glover. It’s a simple set up, and before long you’re rolling around different stages, attempting to roll back the crystals to the cave where the wizard waits.

These magical crystals can change into a bouncy ball, a bowling ball, and a metal ball, with Glover having the power to transform them at any time to meet different challenges. The bouncy ball will float on water, for example, whereas the others will sink to the bottom and can be rolled along. The balls can also be slapped, bounced, and thrown, allowing you to get around. When throwing there is a line that shows you where it will land, but when slapping them there is little true idea of where the ball will end up, which isn’t great when you’re trying to beat a boss.

The game is divided into six stages, each made up of multiple levels. The goal is to navigate these levels with the ball, passing the challenges and defeating the bosses.

From the start Glover is not a fun experience. The levels are barren, the balls can be unwieldy, and movement can be frustrating. This is most evident when you’re trying to float the ball across water while running on top of it to get it to move. The directional input inverts when this happens and it can take a lot of time to get the ball out of the water.

Most of your time will be spent fighting the ball and the controls, instead of navigating the level. The camera is unwieldy – as was tradition at the time and hasn’t been fixed for the remaster – sometimes zooming right up to Glover so you can’t see the level around you. Bosses are also fairly uninspired, and paired with these controls and movement, utterly frustrating to fight. In one boss fight, I also encountered a bug where Glover would start running in mid-air, and not grab the ball properly. Whether this is a new remastered bug, or an old one, I’m not sure, but it shouldn’t be there.

At least the music is pretty catchy.

Summary

Even in its remastered form, Glover is really frustrating to play, and not an enjoyable experience at all. With the amount of games out there and the limited amount of time most of us have, you would be better off getting something else, unless you really want a nostalgic trip to experience a rather bland re-release of a 3D platformer.

Good

  • A great nostalgia buy for die-hard Glover fans
  • The music is good
  • It tried to do something interesting with balls

Bad

  • Frustrating controls
  • Frustrating camera
  • Utterly bland
